body: In a darkened funeral parlor in Chinatown, heavy with the scent of incense and chrysanthemums, an Italian brass band plays ''My Jesus I Love Thee'' at a Buddhist service as family members, illuminated by flickering candles, bow ceremoniously to the deceased, an elderly man lying in an open coffin. On a windswept hillside at Cypress Hills Cemetery,
title: In Mourning, Traditions Mingle; Cultural Exchange in the 'Neighborhoods of the Dead'

body: One summer night 15 years ago, an overheated salesman desperate for a drink blew into the Yellow Rose, a roomy, homey bar a block from the Queens border. ''Thank God, you're the last bar in Brooklyn,'' he said to Addie, the bar's owner, tender, keep and bouncer. (''I'm Addie to the whole world,'' she says, resolutely refusing to give a last name
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CYPRESS HILLS; Bar Is a Borderline Case

body: Hoping to end a long and increasingly bitter dispute involving public school parents and a food company in Brooklyn, the Giuliani administration has announced a plan that would allow construction of a badly needed new school and also allow the company to expand its plant. City officials called the proposal -- under which a coveted parcel on
title: Schools and Industry Clash Over Site in Brooklyn

body: As Buddhist priests in long black robes took turns chanting under towering oaks at the Locust Valley Cemetery here, Misako Rudiger bowed and walked slowly toward a small table laden with fruit, flowers, lighted candles and photographs of the dead. She took a pinch of incense between her fingers, raised it to her forehead, then sprinkled it on a
title: A Place for All Eternity In Their Adopted Land

body: Arthella Addei, the principal of Public School 306 in Brooklyn, has not had much of a summer vacation since school ended in June. She has spent much of her time shuttling between her Long Island home and her East New York office, trying to figure out, among other things, who is going to monitor the school's cafeteria this fall. Last year, four
title: Learning to Do Lunch Without the Teachers

body: A 15-year-old runaway who the police said had been trying to persuade her best friend to stop dating a 33-year-old reputed gang member was shot and killed late Wednesday night in Highland Park in Brooklyn. The police arrested the boyfriend early yesterday morning and charged him with her murder. The victim, Jessica Keohane, 15, whose parents live
title: Police Say Man Killed Runaway, 15, in 3-Way Lover's Quarrel in Brooklyn

body: When their lives first intersected at a high school in the Bronx four years ago, Jonathan M. Levin was a graduate student working as a substitute English teacher and Corey Arthur was a restless 15-year-old in his class, a marijuana-smoking rapper who had committed a robbery and was sliding into deeper trouble. Over the 1993-94 school year, the
title: For Main Suspect in Teacher's Slaying, an Unfocused Life, Marked by Crime

body: The smoke of burning incense curled to the ceiling of a funeral home in Chinatown yesterday, an ephemeral sign that those who loved her wished Wu Quin-Rong all the peace and happiness in her next life that she was denied in this one. Throughout the afternoon, dozens of people made their way down rain-slickened Canal Street to the Hong Kong Funeral
title: Slain Girl Is Mourned in Chinatown

body: Of the nearly 54,000 people who crowded Shea Stadium last night to honor Jackie Robinson, only a handful knew the man who 50 years before broke the color barrier in baseball and changed the range and hue of America's heroes. Rachel and Sharon Robinson, mother and daughter, who joined President Clinton and other dignitaries for the tribute to
title: A Grand Tribute to Robinson and His Moment

body: For a decade, city officials have boasted that nearly three-quarters of New York's streets were acceptably clean. In February, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani released the city's latest self-evaluation, a survey that said 83 percent of the streets were clean -- a remarkable figure considering substantial cuts in the Sanitation Department's budget in
title: A Review Finds the City Dirtier Than It Says It Is

body: Residents of East New York, Brooklyn, who are still waiting for a major supermarket to take root in their poor neighborhood, may at least be able to walk to the movies by the end of the year. National Amusements Inc., which operates more than 1,100 movie theaters, said yesterday that it was preparing to build a $30 million, 14-screen cinema complex
title: The Latest Coming Attraction: Movie House in East New York

body: A car whose driver was trying to avoid a vehicle checkpoint in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon struck a police officer who was working at the roadblock, breaking the officer's ankle, the police said. The police officer, who was not identified, was stopping and checking vehicles at Lincoln and Etna Avenues in the Cypress Hills section when he was
title: Police Officer Is Hurt At Brooklyn Checkpoint

body: A Tiffany stained-glass window believed to be worth hundreds of thousands of dollars was stolen from a mausoleum in a Brooklyn cemetery yesterday morning, the police said. The theft occurred at about 11 A.M. at the Salem Fields Cemetery, which lies right along the border with Queens at 775 Jamaica Avenue near Cypress Hills Street in East New York.
title: A Tiffany Window Is Stolen at Cemetery

body: ELEFTERAKIS-John, M.D., on March 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Dori. Loving father of Maria, John, Nicholas and Michael. Devoted son of Mary and John. Dear brother of Gregory and Valerie; Katherine and Dr. Nicholas Liakas. Reposing at Dahill Funeral Home, 2525 65th St., Brooklyn until Monday 10:00 AM. Funeral liturgy Three Hierarchs G.O. Church 11:00
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ELEFTERAKIS, JOHN, M.D.
